Sure, here's an example:

During a soccer match, the color commentator noticed that one team was consistently passing the ball towards a particular winger in the early stages of the game. The commentator made note of this and explained to the viewers that the team was looking to exploit the weaknesses of the opposition's full-back on that side of the field. Later on in the game, the commentator pointed out that the opposing team had made a change to counteract this strategy, and had brought on a defensive midfielder to cover the full back. When the original team noticed this change, they started to use the opposite winger more frequently. This dynamic was made much clearer to viewers because of the commentator's insights, making the game more engaging and informative to watch.
